title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, are seeking full Federal recognition and the benefits that come with it. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted Federal recognition under the amended Act of June 7, 1956. This recognition extends all laws and regulations of the United States applicable to Indians and Indian tribes to the Lumbee Tribe and its members. Additionally, any group of Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties, North Carolina, not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. Eligibility for services and benefits is also addressed. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget for services in consultation with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for federal services and benefits. The tribal roll, verified by the Secretary of the Interior, defines the service population based on membership criteria in the Tribe's constitution. Verification must be completed within one year of the enactment of this section. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust purposes within Robeson County, North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior will treat the land as on-reservation trust acquisitions. Additionally, state jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state under an agreement with the tribe. This section does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act.
